data.title: Javascript regex syntax coloring bug
Ability to "Lock" a Folder from Opening in the Explorer Tree View
data.body: I have a folder that has a lot of files in it, that are auto generated. Sometimes I need to go into the files, but not very often. When I do it is usually through a "goto definition" command or other method. When you open this file in the editor though, it automatically opens the tree view folder for where the file resides and goes to it. If it's It would be nice to have a feature where you can lock specific folders to stay closed instead of automatically opening and flooding the explorer view with all the files.

data.title: Custom tree explorers should be disposed when the trees are disabled
data.body:
Currently it seems the viewlets are only hidden not disposed, we should free the resources.

/cc @octref

data.title: Remove Mac specific keybindings that don't work
data.body:
The thing that this attempted to provide has never worked. Removing it allows Dvorak keybindings to work correctly. Previously it caused keybindings to use the QWERTY POSITION of the key rather than the actual key.

eg. On Dvorak, the default for insert comments is "Cmd+z" which would then conflict with the undo shortcut.

The current 'fix' does nothing for 'english' based keyboards such as Dvorak, it in fact makes real weird stuff happen because of the 'reverse' mapping it tries to do.

This change will cause some keybindings to be unreachable on some keyboard layouts, but it is my view that it is better to map to the _character_ than the key, and then allow the user (of those keyboard) to map to the _key_ they want to use. (Ie, the problem with the '/' key on the swiss-german keyboard)

data.title: Fix exception on launch.json with empty configurations
data.body:
Issue #15685

**Bug**

Create an empty project with a `launch.json` like this:

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
    ]
}
```

Try to start debugging.

See an exception message

**Fix**
Instead of returning undefined for the promise result, return a promise of null like we do in other cases. This means that we show this message instead of the exception message:

![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 5 55 23 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/20415719/fe84360e-acee-11e6-943a-7ce30c0897ce.png)


closes #15685

data.title: Exception when trying to launch debugger with empty `launch.json`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8


**Steps to Reproduce**

Create an empty project with a `launch.json` like this:

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
    ]
}
```

Try to start debugging.


**Actual**
Exception message:

![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 5 48 29 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/20415569/0176e858-acee-11e6-849a-893590fa6633.png)

We should handle this case better and inform the user that no configurations exist.

data.title: Centered Editor Layout
data.body:
With the recent addition of zen mode, it may be worth considering adding a centered editor layout option:

![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 5 16 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/20414983/3ac9d86c-acea-11e6-9732-0df85effdc66.png)

This is something that the [Typewriter atom extension](https://atom.io/packages/typewriter) adds, and I see it being particularly useful in zen mode and when writing text documents, such as markdown. A centered layout would apply both a softwrap and align the wrapped editor content to the center of the current editor pane.

![screen shot 2016-11-17 at 5 20 45 pm 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/20414982/3ab2d6a8-acea-11e6-8f1f-51de5979e4c2.png)


The major downside is that this would add an ui configuration that we would have to test and support. The centered editor layout also doesn't fit well with all VSCode ui paradigms

data.title: Background square artefacts wrapping text on non-retina display
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: macSierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use Dell U2412M calibrated monitor (using calibrated colour profile, a dedicated .icc file created by x-rite colour meter and its software).
2. Connect to macbook pro early 2015 via thuderbolt or HDMI
3. Open a text file in VS Code

Issue:
Text appear to have a background square shapes wrapping it.
Moving the window to the Retina display, the issue disappears.
Moving back to the Dell monitor, the issue reappears.

Using alias 'code --disable-gpu' in .bash_profile solves the background issue.
However, if in command line interface, VScode cannot open a specific file. It will always default to last used file.
Example:
> code someFile.groovy
Vscode will open the previous opened file, instead of someFile.groovy

Another example:
> code .
VScode won't show current working directory. Instead, it will display previous working file.

Removing the alias from .bash_profile fixes the issues in the examples BUT brings back the background shapes artefacts.

See screenshot.

Is it possible to pass the --disable-gpu argument without breaking the function of opening specific file / folder with VScode?


![_bash_profile_-_gillevy](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8454919/20414670/b70750a6-ad87-11e6-8bd8-9189c2428252.png)

data.title: Convert from 1- to 0-based indexing for TypeScript completion spans
data.body:
Fixes an issue where module and triple slash completions had an off-by-one error with the indexing of text spans. Corresponding issues in the TypeScript repo are:

https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/12165
https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/11462

data.title: Fix TS/JS Implicit Project Too Large Exclude Action
data.body:
Issue #15610

**bug**
For implicit js/ts projects that trigger the large project warning in vscode, the fix/action we currently suggest tries to open a jsconfig.json file in `/dev/null/...`. 

**Fix**
In cases where the `jsconfig.json` file returned by tsserver is not under the root worspace, create an empty `jsconfig.json` at the root of the project instead.



Closes #15610

data.title: enable html autocomplete for a different language
data.body:
I see that you can associate html emmet with other languages (as shown below), but is there some way to do the same for auto-complete?

```
"emmet.syntaxProfiles": {
     "visualforce": "html"
}
```

Seems like there are a 100 (and growing) variants of html, all which use the same core syntax.  It would be very nice to be able to configure html/css auto-complete to work with other variants.

data.title: Move event buffering from BackupService to file models
data.body:
Fixes #14186

---

Summary of changes:

- Move 1000ms event buffer from `BackupService` to the `TextFileEditorModel` and `UntitledEditorModel` content change events.
- `TextFileEditorModel.onDidContentChange` now also fires on reverts
- Amended untitled content change event test to work with new buffer
- Reintroduced the commented out assertions from the text file content change event test and fixed to work with new buffer

data.title: Question: I have a potentially long running operation as part of my extension's installation. Where is the best place to do it?
data.body:
I have a long running operation (searching if a certain npm-package is globally installed, if not, installing it globally) that I need to do as a part of installing my VSCode extension. 

I'm seeking information about what's the best place to do it? 

Initially, I had it in extension activation (with checks to bail early if package is present) and it worked okay. The flipside is that the very first time the user installs the extension, it won't work until the long running operation completes.

So, I'm moving it as a script to be executed during "preinstall" or "postinstall" step. 
```
    "scripts": {
        "preinstall": "node ./install.js"
    },
```

Now, when I Install my extension (from a packaged vsix), I am observing that the npm-package isn't being installed. So, I'm curious if "scripts:{ }" is the right way to go about this? [To be sure, the same script succeeds, if invoked separately from a command prompt.]

I can provide the script i'm using, if required.

Thanks.

data.title: Add support for multiple windows (docking panels) for the bottom panel
data.body:
I moved to Code from Webstorm and never regreted it, VSCode is just great, however I miss one thing which was amazing in WS and it was the support for multiple panels or tabs docked at the bottom of the screen, for example in vscode if I am debugging and have the debugging console open, I cannot see the terminal or some other useful windows that could be displayed in that area of the screen at the same time. It would be awesome to have tabs or the possibility to dock panels at the bottom to make easier switching among the different tools available.  In fact, the ability to dock panels, I think, is what made Visual Studio amazing and is a feature that other editors like Atom, Brackets or Sublime totally lack. 

Hopefully this is something doable and many others like the idea.
